newHome.welcomeSubtitle: Let's protect Our Victorian Ocean Together and Be Ocean Heroes!
speeches: Hi! üê† We are Victorian Ocean Friends! üåä We need your help to protect our home. Join us in learning about the ocean and how you can make a difference! üê¢
Know us better by hovering over the Ocean Friends üêô section in the navigation menu above, then click Meet Our Ocean Friends. Let's explore and have fun together! ‚≠ê

Oh, Hey! ü¶à you can visit our home too! Hover over the Ocean Friends üè† section in the top navigation bar, then click Visit Ocean Friends Home to see where we live and how you can help keep it safe and clean! üåä

Already know us and where we live? Great! üéÆ Let's play some fun games together! Hover over the Play & Practice üéØ section in the navigation menu, then click Play Ocean Fun Games to start playing and learning! üê†

Want to test your ocean knowledge? üìö Hover over the Play & Practice üß† section in the navigation menu, then click Practice Ocean Quiz to challenge yourself with fun questions about marine life! ü§ì

Thank you for visiting us! üôè We hope you have a great time exploring and learning about the ocean. üåä Remember, every little action counts in protecting our beautiful Victorian Ocean. Let's be Ocean Heroes together! ü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüåä

quiz.title: Practice your ocean knowledge
quiz.subtitle: Test your knowledge about our ocean friends and learn how to protect them!

resultMessages.low: Keep trying! You can learn more about our ocean friends and try again.
resultMessages.good: Great job! You have a good understanding of our ocean friends.
resultMessages.excellent: Excellent! You are an ocean hero!

questions.question: Where does most plastic rubbish on the streets end up if it goes into drains?
questions.funFact: Stormwater drains lead straight to the sea, only rain should go down the drain!

questions.question: Why should you avoid swimming at the beach right after heavy rain?
questions.correctAnswer: Rain washes rubbish and germs into the sea
options: Rain washes rubbish and germs into the sea
The water might be too cold
questions.funFact: After heavy rain, it's safer to wait 24-48 hours before swimming.

questions.question: What do sea turtles sometimes mistake plastic bags for?
questions.funFact: Sea turtles often mistake plastic for jellyfish. Use reusable bags to help keep them safe.

questions.question: Where do Little Penguins live in Victoria?
questions.funFact: St Kilda's Little Penguins are world-famous, clean beaches keep them healthy.

questions.question: Which of these is the BEST way to protect the ocean?
questions.funFact: Small actions add up, do all three and you're a true Ocean Hero!

questions.question: What do Burrunan dolphins in Victoria need to stay healthy?
questions.funFact: Dolphins use sound to talk, noisy, polluted water makes life harder for them.

questions.question: Which item belongs in the recycling bin?
questions.funFact: Recycling keeps plastics out of the ocean and gives them a new life!

questions.question: Why do seahorses need seagrass meadows?
questions.funFact: Healthy seagrass = happy seahorses. Pollution destroys their hiding spots.

questions.question: Which of these should NEVER go down a sink or drain?
questions.funFact: Oil sticks to pipes and pollutes waterways. Pour into a container and bin it.

questions.question: How long can a single plastic straw last in the ocean?
questions.funFact: Say no to plastic straws, they can last 200 years in the ocean!

questions.question: How fast can Little Penguins swim?
questions.funFact: Penguins zoom through water at over 6 km/h, faster than many swimmers!

questions.question: Which of these can hurt marine animals?
questions.funFact: Loud boats and sonar confuse whales and dolphins. Quiet oceans = safe oceans.

questions.question: What's the easiest way YOU can help at the beach?
options: Dig a big hole in the sand
questions.funFact: Take 3 for the Sea, every bit of rubbish collected helps marine life.

questions.question: Which of these animals can be found in Port Phillip Bay?
questions.funFact: Burrunan dolphins live only in Victoria & Tasmania, protecting their home is vital.

questions.question: Why is plastic dangerous to seabirds?
questions.correctAnswer: They can eat it by mistake
options: They can eat it by mistake
They can use it as a nest
questions.funFact: Seabirds often think plastic looks like food. Keeping beaches clean keeps them safe.

burrunan-dolphin.name: Burrunan Dolphin
burrunan-dolphin.habitat: Bays and coastal waters of Victoria
lines: Please bin your rubbish and cut loops - ghost lines can tangle my fins.
I'm scared of plastic bags and fishing lines.
Choose reusable bottles. Less plastic, safer oceans!
burrunan-dolphin.sadText: I get trouble when plastic bags float around - I might think they're jellyfish to eat! Ghost fishing lines can tangle around my fins and hurt me really bad.
burrunan-dolphin.happyText: I'm happy when the water is clean and clear! I can play with my dolphin friends and talk to them with clicking sounds. Clean oceans mean healthy fish for me to eat!
threats: Plastic bags and fishing lines can entangle fins and be swallowed.
Boat noise makes it hard to communicate.
Polluted water hurts our skin and health.
help: Bin rubbish and cut plastic loops.
Choose reusable bottles and keep boats slow near dolphins.
Join a beach clean-up with an adult.
fun: We sleep with one half of our brain at a time!

southern-right-whale.name: Southern Right Whale
southern-right-whale.habitat: Southern Ocean and Victorian coastline during winter
lines: Keep balloons away from beaches - we can swallow them by mistake.
Slow boats and "quiet seas" help us talk to our calves.
Support rescue teams that free entangled whales.
southern-right-whale.sadText: I get trouble when balloons fall in the water - they look like yummy jellyfish but make my tummy hurt! Loud boat noises make it hard to talk to my baby whale.
southern-right-whale.happyText: I'm happy when the ocean is quiet and clean! I can sing beautiful whale songs to my family and teach my baby how to swim and find food.
threats: Entanglement in nets and ropes.
Ship strikes and underwater noise.
Ingestion of floating plastics.
help: Keep balloons away from beaches.
Support whale rescue teams.
Enjoy whales from a safe distance.
fun: Mothers and calves rest close to the coast in winter.

australian-fur-seal.name: Australian Fur Seal
australian-fur-seal.habitat: Rocky islands and beaches around Bass Strait
lines: Plastic rings/straps tighten as we grow. Snip them before you bin!
Ghost nets are scary - they trap our necks.
Watch wildlife from a distance. We need space to rest.
australian-fur-seal.sadText: I get trouble when plastic rings get stuck around my neck - they get tighter as I grow bigger! Ghost nets are scary and can trap me underwater.
australian-fur-seal.happyText: I'm happy when I can rest on clean rocks with my seal friends! I love diving for fish in clear water and playing in the waves with my pups.
threats: Plastic rings and straps tighten as we grow.
Ghost nets can trap our necks.
Disturbance at resting sites.
help: Snip plastic rings/straps before binning.
Watch wildlife from a distance.
Take fishing gear home.
fun: We "walk" on land using all four flippers!

little-penguin.name: Little Penguin
little-penguin.habitat: Rocky shores and islands including Phillip Island
lines: Keep beaches clean and dark - lights confuse our chicks.
Please take your fishing hooks home.
Join a mini clean-up with an adult - every small piece helps!
little-penguin.sadText: I get trouble when bright lights shine at night - my baby penguins get confused and can't find their way home to our burrow! Sharp fishing hooks hurt my feet too.
little-penguin.happyText: I'm happy when beaches are dark at night so my chicks can find me! I love waddling on clean sand and diving for little fish in the clear water.
threats: Bright lights confuse chicks at night.
Hooks and lines injure penguins.
Oil and plastics damage feathers and stomachs.
help: Keep beaches clean and dark.
Take fishing hooks and lines home.
Join a mini clean-up with an adult.
fun: We are the world's smallest penguins!

weedy-seadragon.name: Weedy Seadragon
weedy-seadragon.habitat: Kelp and seagrass beds along southern Australia
lines: We love healthy seagrass. Don't trample seagrass beds.
Choose reef-safe sunscreen.
Share what you learn - ocean heroes inspire more heroes!
weedy-seadragon.sadText: I get trouble when people step on my seagrass home - it's where I hide and find tiny shrimp to eat! Chemicals from sunscreen make the water yucky for me.
weedy-seadragon.happyText: I'm happy when my seagrass forest is healthy and green! I can hide among the leafy plants and dance with the gentle currents while looking for tasty treats.
threats: Loss of seagrass and kelp habitat.
Poor water quality.
Disturbance from careless diving.
help: Don't trample seagrass beds.
Choose reef-safe sunscreen.
Share what you learn to inspire ocean heroes!
fun: It's the dads who carry the eggs!

australian-fairy-tern.name: Australian Fairy Tern
lines: Please stay outside our nesting areas on sandy beaches.
Keep dogs on leash near shorebirds.
Tiny plastic looks like food - pick it up!
australian-fairy-tern.sadText: I get trouble when people walk too close to my nest in the sand - it scares me and I might leave my eggs! Tiny plastic pieces look like fish but make me sick.
australian-fairy-tern.happyText: I'm happy when I can build my nest safely on clean sand! I love diving into clear water to catch small fish for my baby chicks.
threats: Nests on open sand-easy to trample.
Dogs and people scare parents from eggs.
Tiny plastics look like food.
help: Stay outside signed nesting areas.
Keep dogs on a leash near shorebirds.
Pick up small plastics.
fun: We nest in little scrapes on the sand!

hooded-plover.name: Hooded Plover (Vic)
hooded-plover.habitat: Open ocean beaches and dune edges
lines: We nest right on the sand - give us space and follow signs.
Leave no holes/forts on beaches - chicks can fall in.
Take your litter - wind can carry it into the sea.
hooded-plover.sadText: I get trouble when people dig holes in the sand - my tiny chicks might fall in and can't get out! Litter blows around and hurts my beach home.
hooded-plover.happyText: I'm happy when the beach is flat and clean! I can run along the sand looking for tiny crabs and worms while my chicks follow me safely.
threats: Nests right on sand-easily trampled.
Holes/forts trap chicks.
Loose dogs disturb parents.
help: Follow beach signs and give us space.
Flatten sand forts and fill holes before you leave.
Keep dogs leashed near shorebirds.
fun: Our eggs look like tiny speckled stones!

short-tailed-shearwater.name: Short-tailed Shearwater
short-tailed-shearwater.habitat: Burrows on islands; long ocean migrations
lines: Lights at night can confuse us - shield lights near the coast.
Oil and plastics hurt our feathers and stomachs.
Choose reusables. Small actions make big waves!
short-tailed-shearwater.sadText: I get trouble when bright lights at night confuse me - I might crash into buildings! Oil and plastic make my feathers dirty and my tummy hurt.
short-tailed-shearwater.happyText: I'm happy when I can fly over dark, clean waters at night! I love traveling long distances with my bird friends and diving for fish in the sparkling ocean.
threats: Bright lights at night can disorient us.
Oil & plastics harm feathers and stomachs.
Predators at nesting colonies.
help: Shield lights near the coast during fledging.
Reduce plastic use and join beach clean-ups.
Observe colonies quietly from a distance.
fun: We fly to the Arctic and back every year!
